comments.commentBody: Ah, I got stuck on two letters!  I didn't know INKSTER and spelled Goolagong's name as YVONNE instead of EVONNE; I thought kitties were PETS instead of POTS and didn't recognize JOE TORRE's name.  But I was very pleased to have solved MORITAT and ORESTEIA, and to have remembered Washington Heights from the years I spent in New York City pre-1968.  Fine puzzle!

Thanks for your description and the amazing memories it brings back for me.  One season on the ice was not near enough; it is in my bones and I long to go back.  Enjoy your time in that special place - I will be living vicariously.

As a UK student I long for the Americanisa(z)tion of our higher education system. I spent some time on exchange at a very well known American College and was flabbergasted by the extraordinary difference in the quality of education I received.

I do come from relative privilege, yet was expected to work two jobs during the summer time to pay my own tuition up front. I felt like I had a stake in my education and was appalled by the mismanagement and poor teaching at my home institution. In the US I was not just treated like a student but a customer. If I saw a failing they were quick to address it. In the UK am treated as an errant and ungrateful teenager if I raise concerns. As a PG I take issues with this.

A good example of the dire state of the system occurred early in my first year at a UK University when I was informed by my subject librarian that the subscriptions for the journals most relevant to my field of study had been cancelled due to a £25M cafeteria building project. Nothing wrong with the old one they just wanted a modern art masterpiece.

Such mismanagement would not survive the free market and although this is not a total fix it is a step in the right direction. At least we are avoiding bankruptcy in the education system with these steps and giving student a stake in their education.

Bravo chaps! Keep the reforms coming!

A bit of holiday cheer at last! That pic of the royals is hilarious.

We'd probably shoot at least a few of our American kids down like contagious rats if they took to the streets to fight for their future the way the students in London are doing.

We're good Americans - take away our homes, jobs, education, health care, basic civil rights, our democracy - we'll let it all go rather than disrupt traffic.

I don't condone violence, but non-violent protest or civil disobedience may be what's needed right now.  Those in power need to understand that we will not let them enrich themselves at our expense without a fight.  They need to realize that if enough people suffer, they will eventually suffer too.

Why can't Americans protest anything. Everyone here (I'm sorry, 80% or something of us) have seen our lives become suddenly very scary: no jobs, layoffs, wage decreases, prices up, benefits cut. Yet no one does anything about AND we vote a ton of Republicans in who are responsible for this and only want tax breaks for the top 2%.

As an American, I am shocked that one can assault and maim police with impunity with little chance of any serious prison time. The trend in Europe is to contain violent miscreants and let them rampage rather than securing the streets. Why? When the heir to the throne who has no political power is attacked, and the police seem impotent, something is seriously amiss in British society and law.

This student protest should tell our Mayor that putting up NYPD cameras
all over Manhattan will do little to stop crime from a large group as London
has just about as many CCTV's as inhabitants.
Regarding the issues involved the British students will now join their American counterparts
in finishing a college education in debt with a poor chance of employment in the job marketplace
to undo that increasing debt.

It was dumb for the Prince's police detail to drive into the middle of that melee.

And let me point out that the Prince, (and the monarchy) for all their faults, are not supposed to be involved in politics. (Remember, the Queen cannot vote, nor can Charles or William as they are in direct line for the throne.) So it was just as dumb for the protesters to attack his car, just like it was dumb for some of them to throw firecrackers under police horses hoping to scare the poor animals (or unseat the cops.)

On the flip side, it was dumb for the cops to kettle many (peaceful) protesters in certain areas of London, thus inciting anger and making a bad situation worse.

And finally, it is supremely dumb that most societies are not willing to value a good education for all citizens that are qualified and willing. For practical reasons perhaps it cannot be free, but it should at least be reasonably priced and open to all who are capable.

All of you people railing about getting stuff for free courtesy of "socialism" realize the English pay VERY high taxes to get those benefits right?

I say go kids!!! Don't back down. Don't be told you have to settle for less just so millionaires and billionares can have it all. Humanity is nearing a crossroads, at the Rubicon so to speak, and we have to make a decision. Do we want to be ruled by a monied oligarchy of tyrants who feel it is their right to have it all, even if it destroys our future by hurting our education and the fabric of our societies, or are we going to have a world where all people are created equal each with an fair chance to succeed? On the present course we are heading backwards towards feudal socieites with obscenely wealthy ruling classes and the abject poor. What we fought to overthrow with the American and French revolutions. It can be done peaceful and civilly...or not. But revolution is in the air...

I wish that American college students could have been more politically active.  If they had, perhaps the U.S. could have avoided the Iraq war or the war could have ended much sooner; the healthcare reform could have included the public option; the economic stimulus could have been more effective with real spending for job creation and less tax giveaways; and the Bush tax cuts for millionaires could have been killed off.

It will be a wonderful day when students in this country show the same passion and anger. But sadly they're too busy posting on facebook, working to pay off student fees, or desperate to conform so they can get a leg up and onto Wall Street. This country needs to take to the streets, as soon as possible. But it won't - only middle class kids threatened with the draft and blacks have ever done it.

Bless the hearts of British youth for protesting a government trying to keep them down by restricting their access to education and saddling them with debt so that the rich and privileged can remain rich and privileged. Students and governements everywhere should take note.

Their “royal highnesses” are symbols & caricatures of the fascists regimes all over the world; totally useless privileged bastards paid for by the same people that now want to chop their heads off.

Nothing so terribly wrong with it. I only﻿ hope the guillotine would be reintroduced﻿ for real culprits of the world’s population sufferings: the Financial Crime Cartel members.

In Britain, this causes riots: "Under the new fees, which are to take effect in 2012, many students are expected to accumulate loans of as much as £40,000, about $63,000, during a three-year degree course. Part of what has stoked anger over the increases is that Britain’s universities traditionally charged no tuition fees, with tuition costs met out of taxpayer grants to colleges or endowment funds."

In the United States, students are expected to shoulder more than this every year of university education. We spend so much on tax cuts for billionaires, invading the wrong country and anti-immigration walls that of course there's nothing left for health care, education or food safety.

FEH!!!!
It will take the downtrodden of western society to wake up before they realize "change" is neccessary.  Not the type touted by politicians, but, the Robespierre sort.

Thank God someone is standing up against this fleecing of the poor and middle class.

The ability to protest is the most fundamental right of any truly democratic society. Once you can no longer protest, because the police have become too strong, then you are a heartbeat away from totalitarianism. Think it can't happen? Look anywhere in history.

Taking away education is also the first step in a totalitarian regime. Take away education and the populace becomes more susceptible to demagoguery, and easier to control.

Finally, we must ask ourselves what is going on. Bankers messed up. And now the government is taking the people's money away from the people (who had nothing to do with the financial crisis), and giving it to the very people who caused the financial crisis, namely the rich bankers.

This is a reverse Robin Hood: take money away from the poor and give it to the rich, so that the rich can become more politically powerful, and then take more money away from the poor.

How much longer does this have to go on before we get out from behind our desks and DO something about it?

Youths did not have any personal reaction against Monarchy but against the rich people deciding to raise their tuition and thus lower the access the higher education.Economical great disparities is starting to create social turmoil in many countries of the world, England is only example of it.

So far things are just below critical mass in the United States, but when it explodes, and it will, the 1960's
will look like a Sunday school picnic. There are ways to avoid the comming confrontations, but the rich politicians and their Wall St. bedmates just keep telling the masses to stick it. There won't be a place on Earth for them to hide when this stuff hits the fan. Prince Charles should be prosecuted for the death of Diana, instead he's riding around town in luxury with that; was that a dog sitting beside him, it wasn't clear on my screen.
I don't believe in violence, but maybe this is the only way to get the message across to the privileged classes.

Well good for the young Brits! There is a class war being waged by the rich and the corporations which is fomented by an international right wing reaction by the wealthy against the middle class. It is being fought with right wing propaganda that says all nations will suffer a horrible impending financial calamity unless we effectuate their right wing agenda which, among several core principles, involves drastic entitlement cut backs for the middle class.

Unlike their American peers, the young in the UK understand that they are being made to pay the bill without having eaten the meal. And like most skeptics, they wonder if the doomsday horrors the international right keeps hollering are neigh will really come to pass if there were no middle class cutbacks. Unlike their American peers, these young Brits also ask why they should have to pay for the disastrous conservative economic policies made by a wealthy and powerful ruling class who became incredulously rich from those very policies across the capitalist world.

The young who are rioting in Britain are at least asking some basic questions. One of the most basic questions we all need to ask is where did the right wing get these prescient powers of prognostication that they are able to so accurately predict doomsday unless we follow their dictates? And then with their prescriptions for economic health, they slash benefits from the middle class that have taken generations to enact and which are wildly successful. Why do we so readily cede the bully pulpit to the right wing when so many of the programs they would dismantle are clearly successful and form the backbone of the middle class?

All they offer us is, "Your entitlements cost too much. If we keep spending like this, the nation will collapse. Here's what to do." We get plenty of doomsday scenarios, but no proof. Why should we believe them? Why should we follow a plan from the same people who caused this mess in the first place?

You know,

Despite this royal dust up- It wouldn't surprise me to see, in a couple more years, as disaffection and alienation continues to rise there (and here) to actually see the Royals or a Royal supporting faction make a play for power. I mean- these "civilian" governments in both the US and UK now seem determinedly engaged in completely discrediting themselves (even if most people don't realize it yet).

Worldwide, populations have remained fairly docile and depressed since the economic "crisis" began just over two years ago, but spreading from Greece, to France, to the U.K., that's beginning to change.  A crowd chanting "off with their heads" while pounding on the Crown Prince's car isn't something to overlook.  How ofter has this sort of thing happened.  Visions of the French Revolution.  We had a similar glimps in Romania at the fall of the Eastern Block.  In the U.S. we have Obama working out a deal with the Republicans to give almost a trillion in debt over to the richest of the rich, while TV talks about cutting Medicare and Social Security, and support for universities is being cut--the very cuts that led to the revolutionary outbreak in London.  Are we heading for one of those "the times they are changing" moments?  Let's hope at least that the principal victims will be the super rich and not the poor and middle class.  Off with their heads, indeed.

too bad this doesnt happen more often
but it might
there a lots of angry folks out there
it would have been beyond wonderful to see their car tipped over
with them in it
pity
all we get is a photo the CPB looking shocked

Ah, the trade-offs of austerity. As much as I hate street violence, this is totally expected. Indeed, it's deserved. And, honestly, I feel this would have been a happy story if only there had been some bankers or bondholders in the car instead.
